issue.title: Metadata is getting structured, FEEDBACK PLS

labels.name: PSA
labels.description: Public Service Announcement

labels.name: feedback wanted
labels.description: We want premium quality opinions on this issue

issue.body:
Up until fairly recently metadata values were stored exclusively as strings, work has been done to accommodate arbitrary and structured metadata values internally and these non-string values are already accessible via plugin APIs. However, in order to preserve backwards compatibility in Bloblang I made it so that assignments support arbitrary values but the traditional functions for accessing those values (the functions `meta` and `root_meta`) will always return strings. This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this:

```coffee
root = meta("structured").parse_json()
```

And if we were to change `meta` in order to yield a structured value when applicable then this mapping would break.

Another unrelated annoyance that has been expressed with metadata in the past is that it's unintuitive that assignments aren't reflected by the `meta` function throughout a mapping unlike variable assignments. This is because `meta` would refer to the immutable input metadata, whereas `root_meta` would refer to the metadata of the message being created.

Finally, another annoyance is that you're forced to use a function with string argument for metadata queries whereas variables are a nicer `$foo` syntax.

In order to address all of these issues in a backwards compatible way I'm planning to deprecate the `meta` and `root_meta` functions (but keep them) and add a new way in which metadata can be queried with a `@foo` syntax. We would also support `root.foo = @` for obtaining an object of all metadata key/values similar to `meta()`. The values returned by the `@` syntax will be metadata values as they currently exist in the message being mapped, so they will reflect changes throughout your mapping similar to variables.

The final outcome will look like this:

```coffee
let origin_meta = @ # Keep a copy of input metadata for later

meta = deleted()
meta user = this.user
meta id = @user.id + uuid_v4()

root.id = @id
root.source.topic = $origin_meta.kafka_topic
```

What do we think? Ugly? Cool? Don't care?

comment.body:
Thanks! That makes a lot of sense and I didn't think of `@.get($foo)` 😅  Works for me!

> Yeah basically if we change meta to return an object instead of a string then any mapping calling parse_json will start throwing mapping errors where they didn't before.

That's what I meant by modifying `parse_json()` to become a no-op if it's input is object or array instead of throwing an error, but I don't like the semantics of that, so it makes sense to leave it as is :)

issue.title: Snowflake_put output: Auth token expires after 4 hours of inactivity

labels.name: outputs
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to outputs

issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. I get the following error: Apparently a snowflake session is only valid for 4 hours. My current, temporary, solution is to restart the benthos client on a schedule. The gosnowflake [config ](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake@v1.6.6#Config) has a `KeepSessionAlive` field that I think would remedy this problem. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? Or perhaps I'm thinking about this incorrectly and there's another way of solving my issue? Thanks, Niclas

comment.body: Sounds good. I added `client_session_keep_alive` (default `false`) in #1559.

labels.name: PSA
labels.description: Public Service Announcement

labels.name: feedback wanted
labels.description: We want premium quality opinions on this issue

issue.body:
Up until fairly recently metadata values were stored exclusively as strings, work has been done to accommodate arbitrary and structured metadata values internally and these non-string values are already accessible via plugin APIs. And if we were to change `meta` in order to yield a structured value when applicable then this mapping would break.

This is because `meta` would refer to the immutable input metadata, whereas `root_meta` would refer to the metadata of the message being created.

Finally, another annoyance is that you're forced to use a function with string argument for metadata queries whereas variables are a nicer `$foo` syntax.

In order to address all of these issues in a backwards compatible way I'm planning to deprecate the `meta` and `root_meta` functions (but keep them) and add a new way in which metadata can be queried with a `@foo` syntax. We would also support `root.foo = @` for obtaining an object of all metadata key/values similar to `meta()`. The final outcome will look like this:

```coffee
let origin_meta = @ # Keep a copy of input metadata for later

meta = deleted()

meta id = @user.id + uuid_v4()

root.id = @id
root.source.topic = $origin_meta.kafka_topic
```

What do we think? Ugly? Cool? Don't care?

comment.body:
W00t! That looks quite awesome. I'm going to be testing the heck out of this 😁 

> This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this
> `root = meta("structured").parse_json()`

I guess `parse_json()` could translate to a no-op if whatever `meta("structured")` returns happens to be an object or an array, so is the worry is that it would no longer raise an error as it currently would when called on an object or an array? That's a good enough reason to not do it, but I'm curious if I'm overlooking something else.

A few more questions:
- Will `@this` raise an error?
- Will it be possible to do smth like `@($foo)` or `@(env("FOO_BAR"))`? If not, then deprecating `meta()` and `root_meta()` might be an issue.

issue.title: Snowflake_put output: Auth token expires after 4 hours of inactivity
issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. I get the following error: Apparently a snowflake session is only valid for 4 hours. My current, temporary, solution is to restart the benthos client on a schedule. The gosnowflake [config ](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake@v1.6.6#Config) has a `KeepSessionAlive` field that I think would remedy this problem. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? Or perhaps I'm thinking about this incorrectly and there's another way of solving my issue? Thanks, Niclas

comment.body: Hey @niclasgrahm, thanks for uncovering this issue! That's really annoying... Guess I didn't get to run Benthos for a long enough time to bump into this issue. According to [this](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/477), setting `KeepSessionAlive` to `true` isn't going to help. However, as documented [here](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/556), we'll need to set the `client_session_keep_alive` in the Config params. I raised a tentative PR [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/pull/1557) to add it. Would you mind testing this if you can clone my branch and build Benthos yourself? You can do that by installing Go 1.18+ and running `make` in the repo. It should produce the `./target/bin/benthos` binary that you can run.

pull_request.title: Fix snowflake_put output token expiry bug
pull_request.body:
This is an attempt to prevent the Snowflake connection from becoming invalid after 4 hours as described [here](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/556).

The change is inspired from [this example](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/blob/82aecfae87c571aa7dfe1c7542e1e48517e79ec8/cmd/keepalive/keepalive.go#L37-L53) in the github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake code.

Fixes #1556.

Hey @twmb, thanks for [the nudge](https://github.com/twmb/franz-go/pull/223#issuecomment-1284886598) :) I think this might just suffice.

Technically, the Docker command should look smth like this, I think (or at least that's what I've been cargo-culting for a while): `docker run --rm -p9092:9092 docker.vectorized.io/vectorized/redpanda:latest start --default-log-level=debug --smp 1 --reserve-memory 0M --overprovisioned --set redpanda.enable_transactions=true --kafka-addr 0.0.0.0:9092 --advertise-kafka-addr redpanda:9092`, but GitHub Actions [doesn't allow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60849745/how-can-i-run-a-command-in-github-action-service-containers) users to overwrite the Docker `CMD` yet, which is a very weird omission IMHO.

issue.body:
Hello.

I have a few custom components for benthos implemented in my own repository and I have several teams using this custom runnable. Currently each team can configure logger, traces, metrics, etc inside their config files.

The problem is that we are implementing few rules and formats that every team must follow but with the current state of benthos we would need to copy and paste this configuration for every single config file of our teams, and no one guarantees that new files will have this configuration

The best scenario for me and my team would be benthos allowing a injection of how the logger is made (being able to inject a interface implementation to override benthos internal logging, for example). But for now the configuration directly on my own golang files would be great!

I'm also happy to contribute, just need some guidance hahaha

issue.title: Input kafka, output snowflake_put fails, "Received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401"

labels.name: outputs
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to outputs

labels.name: needs more info
labels.description: An issue that may be a bug or useful feature, but requires more information

issue.body:
Hello!

I'm trying to use the snowflake_put output to automatically call a snowflake snowpipe and insert the transferred data from a stage to an actual table. I've carefully generated the private/public keys and filled in all the fields in the .yml config as per the [docs](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#account).

The error I'm getting: 
```
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=debug msg="Calling Snowpipe with requestId=57e6eb23-b098-4b76-a0f2-97859ad393f5" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=error msg="Failed to send message to snowflake_put: failed to call Snowpipe: received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
```

Anyone have any idea on how to approach debugging this? Anybody gotten it to work and can share configuration details?

Thanks in advance!

comment.body:
Hey  @niclasgrahm, you're very close to getting it to work if it's able to stage files. Unfortunately, Snowflake makes it rather awkward to troubleshoot Snowpipe failures. Here are some things to try:
- Snowpipe does offer a REST API which you can use to get some information about the errors it encountered. Have a look [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#snowpipe-troubleshooting) for instructions on how to use it. The error might be cryptic in some cases, like when the compression doesn't match (see the next bullet point).
- Make sure the compression matches on both sides. To start, set `NONE` explicitly [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#compression) as well as when creating the Snowpipe. Then you can use the "handsfree" one and set both to `AUTO` (the [gosnowflake](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake) driver will gzip the payloads under the hood in this case). If that doesn't perform well, then you can configure another type of compression and compress the message batches yourself in the Benthos config using the [compress](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/compress) processor.
- Snowflake supports [several file formats](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/create-file-format.html), but the easiest one to use is JSON, since that's the native one that Benthos produces. If you batch messages so you get more than one JSON document in a staged file, then it's fine to simply concatenate them. Benthos lets you [archive](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/archive) them using `format: json_array`, but then you'll need to use `STRIP_OUTER_ARRAY = TRUE` when creating the Snowpipe.
- Use `snowsql` to download one of the files from the stage and have a look at its contents. Is it in the format you expect it to be? If not, consider adding a [`log`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/log) processor at the output level in the Benthos config to see what Benthos is sending.
- Depending on how your Benthos input and processors are configured, the format of each message read from the input and the batching settings, the Snowpipe declaration might need to be adjusted. I think the easiest way to validate this is to run the `COPY INTO ... FROM (SELECT ...)` statement manually once you have a file in stage and make sure it works as expected.

I think this should be enough to get you going, but if you're still stuck, you can try to share some of the information you collected based on the above items and we can see how to proceed. Feel free to join the [community](https://www.benthos.dev/community) for private chats.
Small nit: using append with make(T, 0, len) will avoid initialising the memory with default values

issue.body:
Hello!

I'm trying to use the snowflake_put output to automatically call a snowflake snowpipe and insert the transferred data from a stage to an actual table. I've carefully generated the private/public keys and filled in all the fields in the .yml config as per the [docs](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#account).

The error I'm getting: 
```
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=debug msg="Calling Snowpipe with requestId=57e6eb23-b098-4b76-a0f2-97859ad393f5" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=error msg="Failed to send message to snowflake_put: failed to call Snowpipe: received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output

comment.body: Hey @niclasgrahm, I’ll need more information to help you troubleshoot that (I might need to see the config), but the first thing to check is if you followed [step 4](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/key-pair-auth.html#step-4-assign-the-public-key-to-a-snowflake-user) in the Snowflake docs to associate that key with your Snowflake user. Also, it would help a lot if you can validate that you can use their [snowsql](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide/snowsql-use.html) tool to execute a [PUT](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/user-guide-data-load.html) command using the key you generated.

comment.body:
Hey @lucasoares, I'm wondering if you considered using [CUE](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/configuration/using_cue) instead of yaml for managing configs. For injecting the logger for custom plugins, there's also #1155 and #1080. Please feel free to chime in there too or upvote them.

pull_request.title: Add extra array methods
pull_request.body:
I saw this come up on Slack where someone was looking smth similar to [`index_of`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#index_of) for arrays and thought it might be a good-to-have utility, although after I implemented these methods, I realised that [`enumerated`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#enumerated) can be leveraged for the use case I had in mind. I picked `find` because there's [`std::find`](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/find) in C++ and C# has [`Find` for arrays](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.array.find). I'm OK to rename them to smth else or discard them entirely if they don't really seem useful.

I also did a bit of cleanup in 6865938.

input:

issue.title: Metadata is getting structured, FEEDBACK PLS

labels.name: PSA
labels.description: Public Service Announcement

labels.name: feedback wanted
labels.description: We want premium quality opinions on this issue

issue.body:
Up until fairly recently metadata values were stored exclusively as strings, work has been done to accommodate arbitrary and structured metadata values internally and these non-string values are already accessible via plugin APIs. However, in order to preserve backwards compatibility in Bloblang I made it so that assignments support arbitrary values but the traditional functions for accessing those values (the functions `meta` and `root_meta`) will always return strings. This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this:

```coffee
root = meta("structured").parse_json()
```

And if we were to change `meta` in order to yield a structured value when applicable then this mapping would break.

Another unrelated annoyance that has been expressed with metadata in the past is that it's unintuitive that assignments aren't reflected by the `meta` function throughout a mapping unlike variable assignments. This is because `meta` would refer to the immutable input metadata, whereas `root_meta` would refer to the metadata of the message being created.

Finally, another annoyance is that you're forced to use a function with string argument for metadata queries whereas variables are a nicer `$foo` syntax.

In order to address all of these issues in a backwards compatible way I'm planning to deprecate the `meta` and `root_meta` functions (but keep them) and add a new way in which metadata can be queried with a `@foo` syntax. We would also support `root.foo = @` for obtaining an object of all metadata key/values similar to `meta()`. The values returned by the `@` syntax will be metadata values as they currently exist in the message being mapped, so they will reflect changes throughout your mapping similar to variables.

The final outcome will look like this:

```coffee
let origin_meta = @ # Keep a copy of input metadata for later

meta = deleted()
meta user = this.user
meta id = @user.id + uuid_v4()

root.id = @id
root.source.topic = $origin_meta.kafka_topic
```

What do we think? Ugly? Cool? Don't care?

comment.body:
Thanks! That makes a lot of sense and I didn't think of `@.get($foo)` 😅  Works for me!

> Yeah basically if we change meta to return an object instead of a string then any mapping calling parse_json will start throwing mapping errors where they didn't before.

That's what I meant by modifying `parse_json()` to become a no-op if it's input is object or array instead of throwing an error, but I don't like the semantics of that, so it makes sense to leave it as is :)

issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? comment.body:
W00t! That looks quite awesome. I'm going to be testing the heck out of this 😁 

> This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this
> `root = meta("structured").parse_json()`

I guess `parse_json()` could translate to a no-op if whatever `meta("structured")` returns happens to be an object or an array, so is the worry is that it would no longer raise an error as it currently would when called on an object or an array? - Will `@this` raise an error?

issue.title: Snowflake_put output: Auth token expires after 4 hours of inactivity
issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. I get the following error: Apparently a snowflake session is only valid for 4 hours. My current, temporary, solution is to restart the benthos client on a schedule. The gosnowflake [config ](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake@v1.6.6#Config) has a `KeepSessionAlive` field that I think would remedy this problem. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? Or perhaps I'm thinking about this incorrectly and there's another way of solving my issue? Thanks, Niclas

comment.body: Hey @niclasgrahm, thanks for uncovering this issue! That's really annoying... Guess I didn't get to run Benthos for a long enough time to bump into this issue. According to [this](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/477), setting `KeepSessionAlive` to `true` isn't going to help. However, as documented [here](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/556), we'll need to set the `client_session_keep_alive` in the Config params. I raised a tentative PR [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/pull/1557) to add it. Would you mind testing this if you can clone my branch and build Benthos yourself? You can do that by installing Go 1.18+ and running `make` in the repo. It should produce the `./target/bin/benthos` binary that you can run.

The change is inspired from [this example](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/blob/82aecfae87c571aa7dfe1c7542e1e48517e79ec8/cmd/keepalive/keepalive.go#L37-L53) in the github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake code.

Fixes #1556.

issue.title: Input kafka, output snowflake_put fails, "Received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401"

labels.name: outputs
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to outputs

labels.name: needs more info
labels.description: An issue that may be a bug or useful feature, but requires more information

issue.body:
Hello!

I'm trying to use the snowflake_put output to automatically call a snowflake snowpipe and insert the transferred data from a stage to an actual table. I've carefully generated the private/public keys and filled in all the fields in the .yml config as per the [docs](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#account).

The error I'm getting: 
```
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=debug msg="Calling Snowpipe with requestId=57e6eb23-b098-4b76-a0f2-97859ad393f5" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=error msg="Failed to send message to snowflake_put: failed to call Snowpipe: received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
```

Anyone have any idea on how to approach debugging this? Anybody gotten it to work and can share configuration details?

Thanks in advance!

comment.body:
Hey  @niclasgrahm, you're very close to getting it to work if it's able to stage files. Unfortunately, Snowflake makes it rather awkward to troubleshoot Snowpipe failures. Here are some things to try:
- Snowpipe does offer a REST API which you can use to get some information about the errors it encountered. Have a look [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#snowpipe-troubleshooting) for instructions on how to use it. The error might be cryptic in some cases, like when the compression doesn't match (see the next bullet point).
- Make sure the compression matches on both sides. To start, set `NONE` explicitly [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#compression) as well as when creating the Snowpipe. Then you can use the "handsfree" one and set both to `AUTO` (the [gosnowflake](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake) driver will gzip the payloads under the hood in this case). If that doesn't perform well, then you can configure another type of compression and compress the message batches yourself in the Benthos config using the [compress](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/compress) processor.
- Snowflake supports [several file formats](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/create-file-format.html), but the easiest one to use is JSON, since that's the native one that Benthos produces. If you batch messages so you get more than one JSON document in a staged file, then it's fine to simply concatenate them. Benthos lets you [archive](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/archive) them using `format: json_array`, but then you'll need to use `STRIP_OUTER_ARRAY = TRUE` when creating the Snowpipe.
- Use `snowsql` to download one of the files from the stage and have a look at its contents. Is it in the format you expect it to be? If not, consider adding a [`log`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/log) processor at the output level in the Benthos config to see what Benthos is sending.
- Depending on how your Benthos input and processors are configured, the format of each message read from the input and the batching settings, the Snowpipe declaration might need to be adjusted. I think the easiest way to validate this is to run the `COPY INTO ... FROM (SELECT ...)` statement manually once you have a file in stage and make sure it works as expected.

I think this should be enough to get you going, but if you're still stuck, you can try to share some of the information you collected based on the above items and we can see how to proceed. Feel free to join the [community](https://www.benthos.dev/community) for private chats.
Small nit: using append with make(T, 0, len) will avoid initialising the memory with default values

issue.title: Metadata is getting structured, FEEDBACK PLS

labels.name: PSA
labels.description: Public Service Announcement

labels.name: feedback wanted
labels.description: We want premium quality opinions on this issue

issue.body:
Up until fairly recently metadata values were stored exclusively as strings, work has been done to accommodate arbitrary and structured metadata values internally and these non-string values are already accessible via plugin APIs. However, in order to preserve backwards compatibility in Bloblang I made it so that assignments support arbitrary values but the traditional functions for accessing those values (the functions `meta` and `root_meta`) will always return strings. This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this:

```coffee
root = meta("structured").parse_json()
```

And if we were to change `meta` in order to yield a structured value when applicable then this mapping would break.

Another unrelated annoyance that has been expressed with metadata in the past is that it's unintuitive that assignments aren't reflected by the `meta` function throughout a mapping unlike variable assignments. This is because `meta` would refer to the immutable input metadata, whereas `root_meta` would refer to the metadata of the message being created.

Finally, another annoyance is that you're forced to use a function with string argument for metadata queries whereas variables are a nicer `$foo` syntax.

In order to address all of these issues in a backwards compatible way I'm planning to deprecate the `meta` and `root_meta` functions (but keep them) and add a new way in which metadata can be queried with a `@foo` syntax. We would also support `root.foo = @` for obtaining an object of all metadata key/values similar to `meta()`. The values returned by the `@` syntax will be metadata values as they currently exist in the message being mapped, so they will reflect changes throughout your mapping similar to variables.

The final outcome will look like this:

```coffee
let origin_meta = @ # Keep a copy of input metadata for later

meta = deleted()
meta user = this.user
meta id = @user.id + uuid_v4()

root.id = @id
root.source.topic = $origin_meta.kafka_topic
```

What do we think? Ugly? Cool? Don't care?

comment.body:
Thanks! That makes a lot of sense and I didn't think of `@.get($foo)` 😅  Works for me!

> Yeah basically if we change meta to return an object instead of a string then any mapping calling parse_json will start throwing mapping errors where they didn't before.

That's what I meant by modifying `parse_json()` to become a no-op if it's input is object or array instead of throwing an error, but I don't like the semantics of that, so it makes sense to leave it as is :)

issue.title: Snowflake_put output: Auth token expires after 4 hours of inactivity

labels.name: outputs
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to outputs

issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. I get the following error: Apparently a snowflake session is only valid for 4 hours. My current, temporary, solution is to restart the benthos client on a schedule. The gosnowflake [config ](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake@v1.6.6#Config) has a `KeepSessionAlive` field that I think would remedy this problem. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? Or perhaps I'm thinking about this incorrectly and there's another way of solving my issue? Thanks, Niclas

comment.body: Sounds good. I added `client_session_keep_alive` (default `false`) in #1559.

comment.body:
W00t! That looks quite awesome. I'm going to be testing the heck out of this 😁 

> This is important because existing mappings might be doing things like this
> `root = meta("structured").parse_json()`

I guess `parse_json()` could translate to a no-op if whatever `meta("structured")` returns happens to be an object or an array, so is the worry is that it would no longer raise an error as it currently would when called on an object or an array? That's a good enough reason to not do it, but I'm curious if I'm overlooking something else.

A few more questions:
- Will `@this` raise an error?
- Will it be possible to do smth like `@($foo)` or `@(env("FOO_BAR"))`? If not, then deprecating `meta()` and `root_meta()` might be an issue.

issue.title: Snowflake_put output: Auth token expires after 4 hours of inactivity
issue.body: My setup (kafka input, snowflake_put output) gets its data sporadically, usually in a burst once per day. I get the following error: Apparently a snowflake session is only valid for 4 hours. My current, temporary, solution is to restart the benthos client on a schedule. The gosnowflake [config ](https://pkg.go.dev/github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake@v1.6.6#Config) has a `KeepSessionAlive` field that I think would remedy this problem. Wouldn't it be nice to have this as a param in the snowflake_put config block, and add it [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/blob/547723e3ab6b49881d7f52a1e350d418080a261e/internal/impl/snowflake/output_snowflake_put.go#L563 )? Or perhaps I'm thinking about this incorrectly and there's another way of solving my issue? Thanks, Niclas

comment.body: Hey @niclasgrahm, thanks for uncovering this issue! That's really annoying... Guess I didn't get to run Benthos for a long enough time to bump into this issue. According to [this](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/477), setting `KeepSessionAlive` to `true` isn't going to help. However, as documented [here](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/556), we'll need to set the `client_session_keep_alive` in the Config params. I raised a tentative PR [here](https://github.com/benthosdev/benthos/pull/1557) to add it. Would you mind testing this if you can clone my branch and build Benthos yourself? You can do that by installing Go 1.18+ and running `make` in the repo. It should produce the `./target/bin/benthos` binary that you can run.

pull_request.title: Fix snowflake_put output token expiry bug
pull_request.body:
This is an attempt to prevent the Snowflake connection from becoming invalid after 4 hours as described [here](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/issues/556).

The change is inspired from [this example](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake/blob/82aecfae87c571aa7dfe1c7542e1e48517e79ec8/cmd/keepalive/keepalive.go#L37-L53) in the github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake code.

Fixes #1556.

issue.title: Input kafka, output snowflake_put fails, "Received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401"

labels.name: outputs
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating specifically to outputs

labels.name: needs more info
labels.description: An issue that may be a bug or useful feature, but requires more information

issue.body:
Hello!

I'm trying to use the snowflake_put output to automatically call a snowflake snowpipe and insert the transferred data from a stage to an actual table. I've carefully generated the private/public keys and filled in all the fields in the .yml config as per the [docs](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#account).

The error I'm getting: 
```
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=debug msg="Calling Snowpipe with requestId=57e6eb23-b098-4b76-a0f2-97859ad393f5" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
benthos_snowflake_output   | level=error msg="Failed to send message to snowflake_put: failed to call Snowpipe: received unexpected Snowpipe response status: 401" @service=benthos label="" path=root.output
```

Anyone have any idea on how to approach debugging this? Anybody gotten it to work and can share configuration details?

Thanks in advance!

comment.body:
Hey  @niclasgrahm, you're very close to getting it to work if it's able to stage files. Unfortunately, Snowflake makes it rather awkward to troubleshoot Snowpipe failures. Here are some things to try:
- Snowpipe does offer a REST API which you can use to get some information about the errors it encountered. Have a look [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#snowpipe-troubleshooting) for instructions on how to use it. The error might be cryptic in some cases, like when the compression doesn't match (see the next bullet point).
- Make sure the compression matches on both sides. To start, set `NONE` explicitly [here](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/outputs/snowflake_put#compression) as well as when creating the Snowpipe. Then you can use the "handsfree" one and set both to `AUTO` (the [gosnowflake](https://github.com/snowflakedb/gosnowflake) driver will gzip the payloads under the hood in this case). If that doesn't perform well, then you can configure another type of compression and compress the message batches yourself in the Benthos config using the [compress](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/compress) processor.
- Snowflake supports [several file formats](https://docs.snowflake.com/en/sql-reference/sql/create-file-format.html), but the easiest one to use is JSON, since that's the native one that Benthos produces. If you batch messages so you get more than one JSON document in a staged file, then it's fine to simply concatenate them. Benthos lets you [archive](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/archive) them using `format: json_array`, but then you'll need to use `STRIP_OUTER_ARRAY = TRUE` when creating the Snowpipe.
- Use `snowsql` to download one of the files from the stage and have a look at its contents. Is it in the format you expect it to be? If not, consider adding a [`log`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/components/processors/log) processor at the output level in the Benthos config to see what Benthos is sending.
- Depending on how your Benthos input and processors are configured, the format of each message read from the input and the batching settings, the Snowpipe declaration might need to be adjusted. I think the easiest way to validate this is to run the `COPY INTO ... FROM (SELECT ...)` statement manually once you have a file in stage and make sure it works as expected.

I think this should be enough to get you going, but if you're still stuck, you can try to share some of the information you collected based on the above items and we can see how to proceed. Feel free to join the [community](https://www.benthos.dev/community) for private chats.
Small nit: using append with make(T, 0, len) will avoid initialising the memory with default values

issue.title: Configuring logger, metrics, tracers, etc inside my own GoLang distribution

labels.name: configuration
labels.description: Any tasks or issues relating to Benthos configuration

issue.body:
Hello.

I have a few custom components for benthos implemented in my own repository and I have several teams using this custom runnable. Currently each team can configure logger, traces, metrics, etc inside their config files.

The problem is that we are implementing few rules and formats that every team must follow but with the current state of benthos we would need to copy and paste this configuration for every single config file of our teams, and no one guarantees that new files will have this configuration

The best scenario for me and my team would be benthos allowing a injection of how the logger is made (being able to inject a interface implementation to override benthos internal logging, for example). But for now the configuration directly on my own golang files would be great!

I'm also happy to contribute, just need some guidance hahaha

comment.body:
Hey @lucasoares, I'm wondering if you considered using [CUE](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/configuration/using_cue) instead of yaml for managing configs. With CUE, you could develop a library of standard components which can be used by everyone. If not, I guess it might be handy to allow users to either pass the `-c` argument multiple times or maybe support wildcards for `-c`. WDYT?

For injecting the logger for custom plugins, there's also #1155 and #1080. Please feel free to chime in there too or upvote them.

pull_request.title: Add extra array methods
pull_request.body:
I saw this come up on Slack where someone was looking smth similar to [`index_of`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#index_of) for arrays and thought it might be a good-to-have utility, although after I implemented these methods, I realised that [`enumerated`](https://www.benthos.dev/docs/guides/bloblang/methods#enumerated) can be leveraged for the use case I had in mind. I picked `find` because there's [`std::find`](https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/algorithm/find) in C++ and C# has [`Find` for arrays](https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.array.find). I'm OK to rename them to smth else or discard them entirely if they don't really seem useful.

I also did a bit of cleanup in 6865938.

pull_request.title: Fix Redpanda tests
pull_request.body:
Hey @twmb, thanks for [the nudge](https://github.com/twmb/franz-go/pull/223#issuecomment-1284886598) :) I think this might just suffice.

Technically, the Docker command should look smth like this, I think (or at least that's what I've been cargo-culting for a while): `docker run --rm -p9092:9092 docker.vectorized.io/vectorized/redpanda:latest start --default-log-level=debug --smp 1 --reserve-memory 0M --overprovisioned --set redpanda.enable_transactions=true --kafka-addr 0.0.0.0:9092 --advertise-kafka-addr redpanda:9092`, but GitHub Actions [doesn't allow](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/60849745/how-can-i-run-a-command-in-github-action-service-containers) users to overwrite the Docker `CMD` yet, which is a very weird omission IMHO.
